title: Ricky Gervais defends his ‘dead babies’ joke after bereaved parents walk out of his gig in protest
text:
Ricky Gervais has defended his ‘dead babies’ joke (Picture: Daniel Zuchnik/WireImage) Ricky Gervais has spoken in defence of his ‘dead babies’ joke after a couple walked out of his gig in Belfast on Tuesday. 
Jeremy McConnell cosies up to Stephanie Davis in Twitter pic - are they back together? The comedian has defended the joke on Twitter, saying he sees ‘offence as the collateral damage of free speech’.
Ryan and Suzi Gourley, who were on their first night out together since the stillbirth of their son Eli in July 2016, left partway through Gervais’ show after hearing his joke and went on to make a complaint about it.
Gourley told Belfast Live she wouldn’t have expected the joke ‘in a million years from anybody’ saying it was ‘just wrong’.
But in a series of tweets Gervais defended the fact that he’d caused offence saying he hated the idea that someone might moderate their jokes for fear of causing offence.
He wrote: ‘Jokes about “bad things” don’t have to necessarily be pro those bad things. Surely, a joke that’s anti bad things is a good thing, no?
‘Basically, offence is about feelings, and feelings are personal. People simply don’t like being reminded of bad things.’
Ricky added: ‘All jokes should be banned in case anyone is offended. Discuss.’
Jokes about "bad things" don't have to necessarily be pro those bad things. Surely, a joke that's anti bad things is a good thing, no?
— Ricky Gervais (@rickygervais) March 30, 2017 
Basically, offence is about feelings, and feelings are personal. People simply don't like being reminded of bad things.
— Ricky Gervais (@rickygervais) March 30, 2017 
All jokes should be banned in case anyone is offended. Discuss.
— Ricky Gervais (@rickygervais) March 30, 2017 
Discuss. pic.twitter.com/8DjwSiMxVX 
— Ricky Gervais (@rickygervais) March 30, 2017 

The 55-year-old creator of The Office has been busy on the social media site replying to critics of his joke with a number of people attempting to engage him in a discussion about the ethics of comedy with some pretty gruesome hypothetical situations.
But it seems it would take a lot to make Gervais feel remorseful.
I wish I had a pound for every time I offended someone. Wait, I do.
— Ricky Gervais (@rickygervais) March 30, 2017 

It has not been revealed what was actually said in the joke and Gervais has told his followers on Twitter that they will have to come to his Humanity tour to find out.
Which would be pretty difficult what with all the tour dates being sold out.
Everyone wanting to know what the 'dead baby' joke is either needs to have a ticket for my sold out tour or wait for it to be on Netflix :)
— Ricky Gervais (@rickygervais) March 30, 2017 

The Idiot Abroad creator was not the only one defending the joke.
Some Twitter users were keen to point out that the aim of Gervais’ joke was to make a joke out of his fear of being a bad parent.
The subject of @rickygervais joke was a dead baby – the TARGET of the joke was himself – his fear of being a shit parent. THAT was the joke
— Stevie Robinson (@johnnyutah66) March 30, 2017 
the joke was NOT about dead babies but about Ricky Gervais fear of being a crap parent! Humanity is brilliant! @rickygervais 
— Elisa Cowley (@CowleyElisa) March 30, 2017
